repo.description: Common tools for building TokTok repositories on CI
repo.name: ci-tools

body: The name `travis-haskell` is a bit unfortunate, but this makes it usable from GitHub Actions as well. I could also copy-paste the script and give it a name like `ci-haskell`. Renaming the script would break a lot of our CI due to usage like this: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/master/.travis/cmake-linux#L11-L14. --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/ci-tools/24)

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,22 +13,23 @@ set -eu
 # See below for documentation of each subcommand.
 
 # Determine the Haskell package we're building.
-PACKAGE=$(echo "$TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG" | sed -e 's|^[^/]*/hs-||')
+REPO_SLUG="${TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG:-$GITHUB_REPOSITORY}"
+PACKAGE=$(echo "$REPO_SLUG" | sed -e 's|^[^/]*/hs-||')
 
 # Usage: download [slug] [tool] [output-path] [host]
 #
 # or: travis-haskell download TokTok/ci-tools ci-tools $HOME x86_64-linux
 travis-download() {
-  set -x  # Show execution trace.
-  SLUG="${1:-TokTok/ci-tools}"  # The user/repo on github.
-  TOOL="${2:-ci-tools}"         # The package name to download from the release.
-  ODIR="${3:-$HOME}"            # The output directory where to extract it.
-  HOST="${4:-x86_64-linux}"     # The host platform to download for.
+  set -x                       # Show execution trace.
+  SLUG="${1:-TokTok/ci-tools}" # The user/repo on github.
+  TOOL="${2:-ci-tools}"        # The package name to download from the release.
+  ODIR="${3:-$HOME}"           # The output directory where to extract it.
+  HOST="${4:-x86_64-linux}"    # The host platform to download for.
 
   # Install the latest CI support tools.
   VERSION=$(curl -L -s -H 'Accept: application/json' \
-    "https://github.com/$SLUG/releases/latest" \
-    | python3 -c 'import sys, json; print(json.loads(sys.stdin.read())["tag_name"])')
+    "https://github.com/$SLUG/releases/latest" |
+    python3 -c 'import sys, json; print(json.loads(sys.stdin.read())["tag_name"])')

comment_data.body:
The reason I didn't is because of usage like the one I linked in the PR. It downloads only this one script and executes it, not the entire repo. Turns out it doesn't matter anyway since toktok uses too many minutes and can't use Travis at all anymore, so I'll rename it without a care for backwards-compat. :P

I didn't review the changes the bots made too closely since they're enforced as a rule on the repo. :x Will apply your change to the reformat commit though, thank you! :D
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,22 +13,23 @@ set -eu
 # See below for documentation of each subcommand.
 
 # Determine the Haskell package we're building.
-PACKAGE=$(echo "$TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG" | sed -e 's|^[^/]*/hs-||')
+REPO_SLUG="${TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG:-$GITHUB_REPOSITORY}"
+PACKAGE=$(echo "$REPO_SLUG" | sed -e 's|^[^/]*/hs-||')
 
 # Usage: download [slug] [tool] [output-path] [host]
 #
 # or: travis-haskell download TokTok/ci-tools ci-tools $HOME x86_64-linux
 travis-download() {
-  set -x  # Show execution trace.
-  SLUG="${1:-TokTok/ci-tools}"  # The user/repo on github.
-  TOOL="${2:-ci-tools}"         # The package name to download from the release.
-  ODIR="${3:-$HOME}"            # The output directory where to extract it.
-  HOST="${4:-x86_64-linux}"     # The host platform to download for.
+  set -x                       # Show execution trace.
+  SLUG="${1:-TokTok/ci-tools}" # The user/repo on github.
+  TOOL="${2:-ci-tools}"        # The package name to download from the release.
+  ODIR="${3:-$HOME}"           # The output directory where to extract it.
+  HOST="${4:-x86_64-linux}"    # The host platform to download for.
 
   # Install the latest CI support tools.
   VERSION=$(curl -L -s -H 'Accept: application/json' \
-    "https://github.com/$SLUG/releases/latest" \
-    | python3 -c 'import sys, json; print(json.loads(sys.stdin.read())["tag_name"])')
+    "https://github.com/$SLUG/releases/latest" |
+    python3 -c 'import sys, json; print(json.loads(sys.stdin.read())["tag_name"])')

comment_data.body: Right, essentially all OSS projects need to switch away from Travis anyway (https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25338983), might as well remove all Travis-specific code and references to Travis in the readme.

We're doing haskell differently on GH actions.

commit.message: Add support for GitHub Actions in travis-haskell

repo.description: Common tools for building TokTok repositories on Travis

labels.description: New feature for the user, not a new feature for build script

title: feat: Add support for GitHub Actions in travis-haskell
